elements.content: In a continuation of our interest in pyrazole-based multifunctional metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), we report herein the construction of a series of Cu­(II) MOFs using pyrazole and various 5-substituted isophthalic acids. The central theme is to generate MOFs using the crystal engineering strategy of spacer and node; however, for the node we have introduced a well-known inorganic motif, a [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3] unit. The appearance of the SBU in five MOFs confirms the robustness and reproducibility of the motif with some interesting structures of various dimensionality ranging from 1D helical and 2D herringbone grid to a complex 3D framework. The deployment of bent acids brings chirality via helicity in the system, as further confirmed by solid-state CD spectra. A detailed investigation of the porous MOFs reveals their importance as zeolite analogues for environment remediation. MOF-1–MOF-5 show some interesting photodegradation of harmful organic dyes. MOF-4 and MOF-5 show impressive selective CO2 gas sorption properties. Furthermore, magnetic properties associated with the trinuclear and hexanuclear SBUs of MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5 have also been investigated.

Furthermore, magnetic properties associated with the trinuclear and hexanuclear SBUs of MOF-1 and MOF-3-MOF-5 have also been investigated.

elements.content: In this work we have synthesized a series of MOFs using an well-known inorganic motif, [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)], as the SBU. The resultant MOFs show interesting SBU-based structural networks. The MOFs show efficient photodegradation of toxic organic dyes as well as selective CO2 gas adsorption. The magnetic behavior related to the multinuclear metal clusters has also been investigated.

elements.content: Metal–organic framework (MOF) related research apparently has come of age. This is marked by the paradigm shift from the synthesis of MOFs for potential applications to specific application oriented MOF synthesis. After nearly two decades of research on a relentless pursuit of ever more precise and improved targeted synthetic strategies, uses and applications as well as important markets for the industrial sector are being found for MOFs. The design and synthesis of MOFs were initiated and dominated by the aim of generating porous absorbent materials, which invariably focused on improving physical properties such as enhancing surface area through pore size tuning and topologies of the MOFs. In contrast, chemical knowhow was more or less confined to the self-assembly process and network buildup using a node–spacer concept. The most popular concept superficially used a metal center or cluster as a node, better known as a secondary building unit or SBU, and linked it with an organic ligand as a spacer. For a significant period of time, researchers were more interested in the geometry, direction, and length of the ligand for MOF synthesis rather than utilization of the functional groups for chemical reactivity. Similarly, encrypted chemical features of a particular functional group, metal cluster, or a metal–ligand coordination mode have largely been overlooked for the resultant MOFs, despite their ubiquitous presence and pivotal role in defining various properties in traditional inorganic chemistry.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic framework (MOF) related research apparently has come of age. This is marked by the paradigm shift from the synthesis of MOFs for potential applications to specific application oriented MOF synthesis. After nearly two decades of research on a relentless pursuit of ever more precise and improved targeted synthetic strategies, uses and applications as well as important markets for the industrial sector are being found for MOFs. The design and synthesis of MOFs were initiated and dominated by the aim of generating porous absorbent materials, which invariably focused on improving physical properties such as enhancing surface area through pore size tuning and topologies of the MOFs. In contrast, chemical knowhow was more or less confined to the self-assembly process and network buildup using a node-spacer concept. The most popular concept superficially used a metal center or cluster as a node, better known as a secondary building unit or SBU, and linked it with an organic ligand as a spacer. For a significant period of time, researchers were more interested in the geometry, direction, and length of the ligand for MOF synthesis rather than utilization of the functional groups for chemical reactivity. Similarly, encrypted chemical features of a particular functional group, metal cluster, or a metal-ligand coordination mode have largely been overlooked for the resultant MOFs, despite their ubiquitous presence and pivotal role in defining various properties in traditional inorganic chemistry.

elements.content: One of the most important missing links for this transition, highly relevant to the theme of this work, is the chemical utilization of the so-called SBUs. Of particular interest are SBUs in the form of multinuclear metal clusters. Multinuclear metal clusters are envisaged as the primary reactive sites, yielding various chemical reactivities, which in turn have direct links to the metal coordination environments and their binding modes to the ligands. However, considering the shear dominance of carboxylic acids as ligands, difficulties in controlling large metal–carboxylate cluster formation and nucleating suitable diffraction-quality single crystals made SBUs with higher metal nuclearity a rare event. On the other hand, despite their omnipresence in inorganic chemistry, very few nonmetal–carboxylate cluster based MOFs have been reported in the literature. One such overlooked yet robust and reproducible motif would be the [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3] unit. We have recently demonstrated the usefulness of pyrazole-based metal clusters as SBUs in the synthesis of multifunctional MOFs. The idea was to impart SBU-specific physicochemical properties such as magnetic, spectroscopic, and catalytic properties to the resultant MOFs. For example, one of the MOFs shows an interesting ferromagnetic behavior pertaining to an SBU of a Cu–pyrazolate cluster.

Of particular interest are SBUs in the form of multinuclear metal clusters. Multinuclear metal clusters are envisaged as the primary reactive sites, yielding various chemical reactivities, which in turn have direct links to the metal coordination environments and their binding modes to the ligands. However, considering the shear dominance of carboxylic acids as ligands, difficulties in controlling large metal-carboxylate cluster formation and nucleating suitable diffraction-quality single crystals made SBUs with higher metal nuclearity a rare event. On the other hand, despite their omnipresence in inorganic chemistry, very few nonmetal-carboxylate cluster based MOFs have been reported in the literature. One such overlooked yet robust and reproducible motif would be the [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3] unit. We have recently demonstrated the usefulness of pyrazole-based metal clusters as SBUs in the synthesis of multifunctional MOFs. The idea was to impart SBU-specific physicochemical properties such as magnetic, spectroscopic, and catalytic properties to the resultant MOFs. For example, one of the MOFs shows an interesting ferromagnetic behavior pertaining to an SBU of a Cu-pyrazolate cluster.

elements.content: The obvious question then arose as to whether functional MOFs could be produced with similar Cu–pyrazolate cluster based SBUs. The present paper explores these ideas further, and accordingly we carried out the synthesis of copper-based MOFs with pyrazole and isophthalic acid (H2IPA) and its four 5-substituted derivatives R-H2IPA (R = −CCH, −N3, −OH, −NH2). Keeping in mind that the reproducibility of a robust SBU is a key aim of this study, isophthalic acid derivatives with similar coordinating behavior would be an interesting set of ligands as spacers for MOF synthesis. Another important reason for choosing isophthalic acid derivatives as spacers is their inherent bent conformation, with an angle between the coordinating sites of ca. 120°, which make them ideal candidates for generating helical MOFs. It is imperative to note here that the construction of SBU-based helical networks is a challenging task.

Keeping in mind that the reproducibility of a robust SBU is a key aim of this study, isophthalic acid derivatives with similar coordinating behavior would be an interesting set of ligands as spacers for MOF synthesis. Another important reason for choosing isophthalic acid derivatives as spacers is their inherent bent conformation, with an angle between the coordinating sites of ca. 120°, which make them ideal candidates for generating helical MOFs. It is imperative to note here that the construction of SBU-based helical networks is a challenging task.

elements.content: With the above background, we report herein five novel MOFs, {[Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3(Pyz)­(H2O)­(IPA)]­DMF·CH3OH} n (MOF-1), {[Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3(Pyz)­(H2O)­(DMF)2(HCC-IPA)]­DMF·CH3OH·3H2O} n (MOF-2), {[Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3(Pyz)­(H2O)­(DMF)­(N3-IPA)]·3DMF·2H2O} n (MOF-3), {[Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3(Pyz)­(H2O)­(OH-IPA)]·3DMF·5H2O} n (MOF-4), and {[Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3(H2O)­(NH2-IPA)]·8H2O} n (MOF-5) (where HPyz = 1H-pyrazole, R-H2IPA = 5-substititued isophthalic acid (R = −CCH, −N3, −OH, −NH2). In excellent agreement with our synthetic goal, structural studies show that all five MOFs are formed with Cu–pyrazolate cluster based SBUs. This enhances the possibility of achieving our central goal of generating multifunctional MOFs by incorporating Cu–pyrazolate SBU-specific physicochemical properties: viz, magnetism and catalysis. Indeed, the resultant MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5 show interesting magnetic properties originating from their SBUs. They also show excellent photocatalytic toxic dye degradation properties. Furthermore, MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5 have an impressive ability to capture CO2 gas, offering a solution to environmental pollution.
elements.clean_text: With the above background, we report herein five novel MOFs, {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3(Pyz)(H2O)(IPA)]DMF⋅CH3OH} n  (MOF-1), {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3(Pyz)(H2O)(DMF)2(HCC-IPA)]DMF⋅CH3OH⋅3H2O} n  (MOF-2), {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3(Pyz)(H2O)(DMF)(N3-IPA)]⋅3DMF⋅2H2O} n  (MOF-3), {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3(Pyz)(H2O)(OH-IPA)]⋅3DMF⋅5H2O} n  (MOF-4), and {[Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3(H2O)(NH2-IPA)]⋅8H2O} n  (MOF-5) (where HPyz = 1H-pyrazole, R-H2IPA = 5-substititued isophthalic acid (R = -CCH, -N3, -OH, -NH2). In excellent agreement with our synthetic goal, structural studies show that all five MOFs are formed with Cu-pyrazolate cluster based SBUs. This enhances the possibility of achieving our central goal of generating multifunctional MOFs by incorporating Cu-pyrazolate SBU-specific physicochemical properties: viz, magnetism and catalysis. Indeed, the resultant MOF-1 and MOF-3-MOF-5 show interesting magnetic properties originating from their SBUs. They also show excellent photocatalytic toxic dye degradation properties. Furthermore, MOF-1 and MOF-3-MOF-5 have an impressive ability to capture CO2 gas, offering a solution to environmental pollution.

elements.content: As mentioned above, our strategy is to combine a well-known inorganic metal cluster based functional structural motif with linkers commonly used in crystal engineering in a synthetic approach to generate functional MOFs. It is noteworthy here that depending on the reaction conditions, metal salts, or substituent on the pyrazole ring, a wide range of metal–pyrazolate clusters are known to exist in the literature with varying nuclearities and metal–pyrazolate coordination modes. Although varying nuclearities and coordination modes may lead to interesting properties, as far as robustness of the synthetic design is concerned, any variation in SBU can be conceived as an unwarranted interference with reproducibility. Naturally, our primary aim was to find out if any unique Cu–pyrazolate cluster appears irrespective of the substituent of the isophthalic acid derivatives. It is gratifying to note that for all of the structures the SBUs are indeed based on a unique [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3]2+ unit, consisting of three copper atoms bridged by a μ3-hydroxy group and three μ-pyrazolate anions (). For MOF-1–MOF-4, two Cu centers of the cluster are linked to two monodentate carboxylic acids while the third Cu center is coordinated to one protonated 1H-pyrazole unit; henceforth, the whole unit will be denoted as SBU-I. The Cu–OH bond distances between μ3-OH and Cu atoms of the archetypal triangular core vary from 1.975 to 2.099 Å, shereas the out-of-plane deviation from the plane of the triangular [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3]2+ units varies from 0.321 to 0.582 Å. On the other hand, the Cu–NPyz bonds forming the periphery of the trinuclear core vary from 1.910 to 2.039 Å.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

As mentioned above, our strategy is to combine a well-known inorganic metal cluster based functional structural motif with linkers commonly used in crystal engineering in a synthetic approach to generate functional MOFs. It is noteworthy here that depending on the reaction conditions, metal salts, or substituent on the pyrazole ring, a wide range of metal-pyrazolate clusters are known to exist in the literature with varying nuclearities and metal-pyrazolate coordination modes. Although varying nuclearities and coordination modes may lead to interesting properties, as far as robustness of the synthetic design is concerned, any variation in SBU can be conceived as an unwarranted interference with reproducibility. Naturally, our primary aim was to find out if any unique Cu-pyrazolate cluster appears irrespective of the substituent of the isophthalic acid derivatives. It is gratifying to note that for all of the structures the SBUs are indeed based on a unique [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3]2+ unit, consisting of three copper atoms bridged by a μ3-hydroxy group and three μ-pyrazolate anions (). For MOF-1-MOF-4, two Cu centers of the cluster are linked to two monodentate carboxylic acids while the third Cu center is coordinated to one protonated 1H-pyrazole unit; henceforth, the whole unit will be denoted as SBU-I. The Cu-OH bond distances between μ3-OH and Cu atoms of the archetypal triangular core vary from 1.975 to 2.099 Å, shereas the out-of-plane deviation from the plane of the triangular [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3]2+ units varies from 0.321 to 0.582 Å. On the other hand, the Cu-NPyz bonds forming the periphery of the trinuclear core vary from 1.910 to 2.039 Å.

elements.content: Representative units of (a) [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3]2+ (SBU-I) and (b) SBU-II, resulting from the combination of two units of SBU-I.
elements.clean_text: 1  Representative units of (a) [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3]2+ (SBU-I) and (b) SBU-II, resulting from the combination of two units of SBU-I.

elements.content: The X-ray single-crystal structure analyses of MOF-1 and MOF-2 show the formation of interesting one-dimensional helical networks (). The asymmetric units of both MOFs contain a basic unit of SBU-I, the isophathalic acid derivative, and lattice solvents. The structural features of MOF-1 and MOF-2 were dominated by the helical character induced by the bent isophthalic acid, a well-known linker for generating a helical network. The angular dispositions of the adjacent metal centers with respect to the centroid (Cg) of the IPA molecules (∠Cu–Cg–Cu), which can be considered as the main determinant for helical features, are found to be 125.97 and 123.75°, respectively, for MOF-1 and MOF-2. Subsequently, the carboxylate groups of IPA molecules connect the two SBU-I units from two ends and result in an infinite helical chain. It is noteworthy here that structural examples of metal cluster SBU based helical character have scarcely been reported in the literature. Interestingly, a closer inspection of the structure reveals a coexistence of two kinds of SBU-based helical networks, a left-handed and a right-handed helical network, arranged in an alternative array.

elements.content: Alternative array of left-handed and right-handed infinite 1D helical networks of (a) MOF-1 and (b) MOF-2. Note that coordinated and lattice solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  Alternative array of left-handed and right-handed infinite 1D helical networks of (a) MOF-1 and (b) MOF-2. Note that coordinated and lattice solvent molecules are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The crystal structures of MOF-3 () and MOF-4 () show a slight deviation from the above structure, though the SBU-I-based network formation is a recurring theme. Unlike the other two substituents of isophthalic acids, the azide and hydroxyl groups take part in metal coordination and transform the above 1D helical network to a 2D network. Despite their similarity, the subtle change in orientation of azide group in comparison to the ethynyl group brings a drastic change in the structural topology of MOF-3. Because of the bent conformation, one of the N atoms of the azide group comes very close to a Cu atom of the adjacent SBU-I and coordinates. This, in effect, joins two juxtaposed oppositely handed helical strands to form a 2D network. Interestingly, a similar type of network was formed for MOF-4 when a hydroxyl derivative was employed. However, the basic structural motif in the asymmetric unit remains the same with a triangular [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3]2+ unit and isophthalic acid derivative. Subsequently, the resultant networks can be described as an interesting herringbone type (4,3) grid network, where the SBU-I units act as nodes.

elements.content: Crystal structure of MOF-4 showing (a) a SBU-I based (4,3) type 2D network. Note that hydroxyl groups are highlighted with pink colors in order to illustrate (b) their interlocking coordination to Cu atoms of SBU-I units of two juxtaposed left-handed and right-handed infinite 1D helical strands. (c) 3D packing illustrating the herringbone network and the presence of porous columnar channels.

elements.content: The dimensions of the grid networks are 21.96 × 10.74 Å and 21.78 × 11.12 Å (based on the distances between two diagonal μ3-OH oxygen atoms) for MOF-3 and MOF-4, respectively. However, a closer look reveals an interesting link between the grid networks and other helical structures. Topologically, two axes of the grid network closely resemble those of the alternative arrangement of left-handed and right-handed helical networks, further facilitated by the bent conformation of isophthalic acids with ∠Cu–Cg–Cu values of 120.12 and 118.9°. The protruded hydroxyl groups of the juxtaposed oppositely handed helical networks interlocked with each other at the turnover point through metal coordination, as illustrated in by purple C–O bonds.

elements.content: The 2D grid networks subsequently undergo stacking along the crystallographic a axis, sustained by various intergrid hydrogen bonds, π–π stacking, and weak interactions. This results in an interesting situation with a considerable amount of cavities inside a noninterpenetrating network. However, as far as the void space inside the cavity is concerned, a contrasting picture can be observed for MOF-3 and MOF-4. The volume of the total solvent-accessible void space calculated by PLATON was found to be negligible for MOF-3, while that of MOF-4 is 471.7 Å3, which is approximately 13% of the unit cell volume. This is consistent with crystal structures with MOF-3 where pore channels are mostly filled with coordinated as well as lattice solvent molecules.

elements.content: On the other hand, MOF-5 forms an interesting three-dimensional grid network. Apart from the recurring presence of a triangular [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3]2+ unit and isophthalic acid derivative, the most important feature of the asymmetric unit (orthorhombic, P212121) is the presence of two different types of amine groups; while one of them coordinates to the metal center, the second remains free. Interestingly, unlike previous structures, the carboxylates of IPA clump two such symmetry-equivalent [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3] from two ends with a syn–anti coordination mode, and this results in a centrosymmetric hexanuclear Cu6 core, which henceforth is referred to as SBU-II.
elements.clean_text: On the other hand, MOF-5 forms an interesting three-dimensional grid network. Apart from the recurring presence of a triangular [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3]2+ unit and isophthalic acid derivative, the most important feature of the asymmetric unit (orthorhombic, P212121) is the presence of two different types of amine groups; while one of them coordinates to the metal center, the second remains free. Interestingly, unlike previous structures, the carboxylates of IPA clump two such symmetry-equivalent [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3] from two ends with a syn-anti coordination mode, and this results in a centrosymmetric hexanuclear Cu6 core, which henceforth is referred to as SBU-II.

elements.content: Apparently, the relative orientation of the carboxylic groups plays an important role in the network building MOF-5. The resulting network turns out to be nonhelical in nature, which can broadly be rationalized from a more flattened ∠Cu–Cg–Cu value of 137.24°. Topologically, the complex 3D frameworks can easily be described in terms of (4,4) type grid networks, which are formed when carboxylate groups of IPA molecules act as linkers and join Cu6 units (SBU-II, as vertex). Interestingly, around halfway down each axis, four amine groups protrude from each grid unit. Out of these four, two protruding amine groups coordinate with the perched grids (illustrated as pink IPA molecules in ), one from above and another from below the plane of the grid. This effectively results in vertical expansion of 2D grid networks to form a 3D network.

elements.content: Although the effective void space is reduced considerably because of the offset arrangement of 2D grid networks, the presence of free amine groups in the network is immensely important from a sorption point of view, and as discussed in a later section, MOF-5 indeed shows some interesting absorbent behavior.

elements.content: Organic dyes, in particular azo-based compounds, contribute greatly to water pollution, causing severe disruption in the aquatic ecosystem. The typical physiochemical ways of removing dyes from wastewater is quite costly and require multistep treatment. There is a genuine need for developing a low-cost and efficient technology. One such promising technique would be heterogeneous catalysts such as Fenton catalysts based on transition metals, which eventually oxidize contaminating dye molecules. MOFs are emerging potential photocatalysts in this field with supplementary large surface area as well as unsaturated metal centers. The process of Fenton oxidation involves H2O2, which generate hydroxyl radicals to degrade dye molecules. However, the reaction rate is usually very slow and requires the presence of a catalyst for faster and efficient degradation.
elements.clean_text:
Toxic Organic Dye Degradation Studies

Organic dyes, in particular azo-based compounds, contribute greatly to water pollution, causing severe disruption in the aquatic ecosystem. The typical physiochemical ways of removing dyes from wastewater is quite costly and require multistep treatment. There is a genuine need for developing a low-cost and efficient technology. One such promising technique would be heterogeneous catalysts such as Fenton catalysts based on transition metals, which eventually oxidize contaminating dye molecules. MOFs are emerging potential photocatalysts in this field with supplementary large surface area as well as unsaturated metal centers. The process of Fenton oxidation involves H2O2, which generate hydroxyl radicals to degrade dye molecules. However, the reaction rate is usually very slow and requires the presence of a catalyst for faster and efficient degradation.

elements.content: In the present context, the recurring presence of [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3] motifs in the above structures not only bring the recurring presence of open metal sites but also enhance the possibility of inducing Cu–pyrazolate SBU specific catalysis. Metal centers with unsaturated coordination or with weakly coordinated solvents are often considered to be prerequisites for catalytic activity. Accordingly, the potential of the MOFs for photocatalytic degradation of toxic environmental pollutants were investigated using Congo red and methylene blue dye solutions. In the absence of H2O2, addition of MOF-1–MOF-5 do not cause any noticeable change in color or intensity of the dye solutions. However, addition of 1–2 drops of H2O2 bleaches the bright colors of the dye solutions (Figure ). For the present study, 3 drops of 30% H2O2 were added, followed by ca. 5 mg of the corresponding MOF in the solutions of either Congo red or methylene blue and the progress of the reaction was monitored spectroscopically at room temperature. The intensity of the characteristic peaks, 665 nm for methylene blue and 500 nm for Congo red, started to decrease gradually ( and ). It was noted that after 80 min almost 80% of methylene blue and within 60 min around 85% of Congo red were degraded (). Furthermore, the presence of isosbestic points at ∼490 nm in the case of Congo red and at ∼580 nm in the photodegradation process of methylene blue affirms the formation of new compounds after the degradation of the respective dyes.

elements.content: The mechanism of this reaction can be given by two alternative pathways, namely the “complex” pathway and “free radical” pathway, as suggested by Lekchiri et al. and Gray, respectively. For the complex pathway the metal center containing ligands reacts with H2O2 within the coordination sphere. The reaction steps can be presented as follows: H 2 O 2 → H + + HOO Cu II L + HOO → [ Cu II L ( OOH ) ] [ Cu II L ( OOH ) ] + H 2 O 2 → [ Cu II L ( OOH ) ( H 2 O 2 ) ] [ Cu II L ( OOH ) ( H 2 O 2 ) ] → Cu II L + O 2 + H 2 O + HO However, in the “free radical” pathway it was suggested that both in the presence and in the absence of any ligand, CuII reacts with H2O2 to produce CuI and O2̇•–, which ultimately leads to the formation of HO• radical in a “Fenton-like” fashion: H 2 O 2 → H + + HOO Cu II + HOO − → Cu I + H O 2 • H O 2 • → H + + O 2 • Cu I + H 2 O 2 → Cu II + H O • + OH

MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5 possess three intrinsic characteristic features that can be envisaged as the most important prerequisites for an adsorbent material: viz, a porous network with (a) open metal sites, (b) distinct solvent-filled channels, and (c) immobilized functional groups on the porous surface pointing into pores as well as interlayer spaces. The presence of such structural features facilitates direct interaction with foreign guest molecules. The presence of immobilized N-rich functional groups, such as −N3 and −NH2 in MOF-3 and MOF-5, respectively, are known to have a good effect on enhancing the CO2 adsorption properties, which in effect can play a pivotal role in enhancing gas-separation selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Studies

 MOF-1 and MOF-3-MOF-5 possess three intrinsic characteristic features that can be envisaged as the most important prerequisites for an adsorbent material: viz, a porous network with (a) open metal sites, (b) distinct solvent-filled channels, and (c) immobilized functional groups on the porous surface pointing into pores as well as interlayer spaces. The presence of such structural features facilitates direct interaction with foreign guest molecules. The presence of immobilized N-rich functional groups, such as -N3 and -NH2 in MOF-3 and MOF-5, respectively, are known to have a good effect on enhancing the CO2 adsorption properties, which in effect can play a pivotal role in enhancing gas-separation selectivity.

elements.content: The above considerations prompted us to investigate the N2, CO2, and CH4 gas sorption behavior of MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5. To perform the study, the MOF samples were first soaked in a methanol and DCM (1/1) solution for 12 h in order to exchange the trapped solvent molecules. After the solvent exchange process was repeated three times, the samples were then dried under vacuum at 110 °C before being taken to the instrument. Nitrogen gas sorption was carried out at 77 K to determine the surface area under the pressure range of 0–1 atm. However, CO2 and methane gas adsorption studies were done at 273 K in the aforementioned pressure range. All three MOFs exhibit moderate to poor uptake of N2 gas. MOF-1 and MOF-3 absorbed 20 and 40 cm3/g, respectively (Figures S17 and S18 in the Supporting Information), whereas MOF-4 and MOF-5 absorbed ca. 7 and 10 cm3/g of N2, respectively. Interestingly, both MOF-4 and MOF-5 show reasonably high uptake of CO2, which are in stark contrast to the absorbance properties of MOF-1 and MOF-3 with poor uptake. Both MOFs show a typical type I isotherm, and as the pressure approaches 1 atm the adsorption of CO2 reaches a plateau at 23.1 and 38 cm3/g for MOF-4 and MOF-5, respectively (). In order to confirm the selective CO2 gas sorption over other gases, we also performed CH4 gas sorption studies for all three MOFs. The results show poor uptake of CH4 gas and henceforth confirmed the selective CO2 gas sorption ability of MOF-4 and MOF-5.

elements.content: Chirality is a fundamental property of any chemical substance, as the biological systems are homochiral. Generally, a chiral ligand gives chiral complexes or polymers, but at times an achiral ligand may also give chiral complexes through the process of spontaneous resolution. Helicity, on the other hand, has some interesting hand in hand relation with chirality, as helical self-assembly of even achiral substances has the tendency to induce chirality in the system. However, chirality of an inorganic compound is often overlooked despite its importance in chiral catalysis, separations, or bioinorganic systems. For the present case, MOF-4 and both MOF-1 and MOF-5 crystallize in chiral space groups P21 and P212121, respectively, and also adopt helical topology. This led us to explore the chirality of those MOFs using solid-state circular dichroism CD spectroscopy with the diffuse reluctance technique over a KBr matrix. Interestingly the CD spectra of MOF-1 and MOF-4 showed both positive and negative Cotton effects.
elements.clean_text:
Chirality

Chirality is a fundamental property of any chemical substance, as the biological systems are homochiral. Generally, a chiral ligand gives chiral complexes or polymers, but at times an achiral ligand may also give chiral complexes through the process of spontaneous resolution. Helicity, on the other hand, has some interesting hand in hand relation with chirality, as helical self-assembly of even achiral substances has the tendency to induce chirality in the system. However, chirality of an inorganic compound is often overlooked despite its importance in chiral catalysis, separations, or bioinorganic systems. For the present case, MOF-4 and both MOF-1 and MOF-5 crystallize in chiral space groups P21 and P212121, respectively, and also adopt helical topology. This led us to explore the chirality of those MOFs using solid-state circular dichroism CD spectroscopy with the diffuse reluctance technique over a KBr matrix. Interestingly the CD spectra of MOF-1 and MOF-4 showed both positive and negative Cotton effects.

elements.content: Signals for MOF-1 appear around 290, 605, and 385 nm, while those of MOF-4 are observed around 210, 245, 270, and 300 nm. In contrast, MOF-5 shows a negative Cotton effect having peaks at 209 and 222 nm which are characteristic peaks of an α-helix system (). We repeated the CD measurements using MOFs generated from different batches, and the respective spectra showed exactly similar Cotton effects, which confirms that the compounds formed are enantiomerically pure. Considering the fact that systems do not possess any chiral ligand or any chiral environment around the metal center, the origin of chirality can be attributed to the self-assembly of helical motifs of the respective MOFs.

We repeated the CD measurements using MOFs generated from different batches, and the respective spectra showed exactly similar Cotton effects, which confirms that the compounds formed are enantiomerically pure. Considering the fact that systems do not possess any chiral ligand or any chiral environment around the metal center, the origin of chirality can be attributed to the self-assembly of helical motifs of the respective MOFs.

elements.content: dc magnetic susceptibilities were performed on polycrystalline samples of MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5 (). Room-temperature χM T (χM = molar magnetic susceptibility) values are 0.98, 1.0, 1.06, 1.61 cm3 mol–1 K for MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5, respectively. All of the χM T values at 300 K are lower than the theoretical calculated value of 1.125 cm3 mol–1 K for three uncoupled Cu­(II) centers (g = 2) for MOF-1, MOF-3, and MOF-4, whereas the theoretical value of six uncoupled Cu­(II) centers (g = 2) is 2.25 cm3 mol–1 K (g = 2) for MOF-5. Lower values are most probably due to the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions at room temperature. χM T plots are decreased with a decrease in the temperature due to antiferromagnetic exchange with neighboring Cu­(II) centers. Minimum values of 0.31, 0.15, 0.38, and 0.45 cm3 mol–1 K were obtained at 2 K for MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5, respectively. We tried to fit the magnetic data using the model. However, due to the large number of magnetic exchange pathways with complicated structures, it was not possible to fit with any simplified model.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Studies

dc magnetic susceptibilities were performed on polycrystalline samples of MOF-1 and MOF-3-MOF-5 (). Room-temperature χM T (χM = molar magnetic susceptibility) values are 0.98, 1.0, 1.06, 1.61 cm3 mol-1 K for MOF-1 and MOF-3-MOF-5, respectively. All of the χM T values at 300 K are lower than the theoretical calculated value of 1.125 cm3 mol-1 K for three uncoupled Cu(II) centers (g = 2) for MOF-1, MOF-3, and MOF-4, whereas the theoretical value of six uncoupled Cu(II) centers (g = 2) is 2.25 cm3 mol-1 K (g = 2) for MOF-5. Lower values are most probably due to the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions at room temperature. χM T plots are decreased with a decrease in the temperature due to antiferromagnetic exchange with neighboring Cu(II) centers. Minimum values of 0.31, 0.15, 0.38, and 0.45 cm3 mol-1 K were obtained at 2 K for MOF-1 and MOF-3-MOF-5, respectively. We tried to fit the magnetic data using the model. However, due to the large number of magnetic exchange pathways with complicated structures, it was not possible to fit with any simplified model.

elements.content: Hence, we have plotted 1/χM vs T and fitted the plot with the Curie–Weiss equation, χM = C/(T – Θ), where C = Curie constant and Θ = Curie–Weiss constant (). The best-fitted values were C = 2.35 cm3 mol–1 K and Θ = −143.1 K for MOF-5, C = 2.1 cm3 mol–1 K and Θ = −317.5 K for MOF-4, C = 1.29 cm3 mol–1 K and Θ = −319.5 K for MOF-3, and C = 1.55 cm3 mol–1 K and Θ = −181.4 K for MOF-1. The large negative values for all of the complexes suggest the presence of dominant strong antiferromagnetic interactions. Antiferromagnetic exchange is stronger for MOF-3 and MOF-4 in comparison to MOF-1 and MOF-5.

elements.content: Further, to examine the low-temperature behavior, the experimental data were fitted using the noncritical-scaling theory with the phenomenological equation χ M T = A exp ( − E 1 / k T ) + B exp ( − E 2 / k T ) where E 1 > 0 indicates the activation energies corresponding to the spin–orbit coupling, E 2 represents the antiferromagnetic exchange interactions, and A + B equals the Curie constant. From the fitting E 1/k = 5.73 cm–1, E 2/k = 309.4 cm–1, and A + B = 2.45 cm3 K mol–1 were obtained for MOF-5. The A + B value is close to the Curie constant of the amine. A low value of E 1/k suggests low spin–orbit coupling, whereas a high value of E 2/k suggests strong antiferromagnetic exchange in the system. For MOF-4, E 1/k = 1.25 cm–1, E 2/k = 226.5 cm–1, and A + B = 2.00 cm3 K mol–1, for MOF-3, E 1/k = 5.2 cm–1, E 2/k = 304.5 cm–1, and A+ B = 1.37 cm3 K mol–1, and for MOF 1, E 1/k = 6.4 cm–1, E 2/k = 365.5 cm–1, and A+ B = 1.76 cm3 K mol–1. Similar to the case for MOF-5, A + B values are close to the Curie constant and the value of E 1/k is very low in comparison to E 2/k for MOF-1, MOF-3, and MOF-4, suggesting strong antiferromagnetic exchange and low spin–orbit coupling.

elements.content: The impetus for the work presented herein was to design multifunctional MOFs by using an well-known inorganic motif, [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3], as the SBU and thereby inducing properties related to the Cu–pyrazolate unit. Accordingly, we have synthesized a series of trinuclear [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3] unit based MOFs by systematically varying the substituents of R-H2IPA molecules. All of these MOFs are found to be built on the above SBU, thus confirming the reproducibility. This also leads to the formation of a wide range of SBU-based networks ranging from 1D helical strands and a 2D (4,3) type herringbone grid to a complex 3D porous framework. We have also successfully demonstrated our strategy of generating multifunctional MOFs by the use of SBU-specific properties. Solid-state CD spectra of MOF-1, MOF-4, and MOF-5 are consistent with the presence of SBU-based helical motifs. MOF-3–MOF-5 show excellent selective CO2 gas sorption. Toxic organic dye degradation properties with potential applications in environmental remediation and wastewater purification were found for all of the MOFs. Furthermore, trinuclear and hexanuclear Cu–pyrazolate unit (SBU-I and SBU-II) induced magnetic behavior of MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5 highlights the usefulness of [Cu3(μ3-OH)­(μ-Pyz)3] cluster based SBUs for magnetic MOF synthesis.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The impetus for the work presented herein was to design multifunctional MOFs by using an well-known inorganic motif, [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3], as the SBU and thereby inducing properties related to the Cu-pyrazolate unit. Accordingly, we have synthesized a series of trinuclear [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3] unit based MOFs by systematically varying the substituents of R-H2IPA molecules. All of these MOFs are found to be built on the above SBU, thus confirming the reproducibility. This also leads to the formation of a wide range of SBU-based networks ranging from 1D helical strands and a 2D (4,3) type herringbone grid to a complex 3D porous framework. We have also successfully demonstrated our strategy of generating multifunctional MOFs by the use of SBU-specific properties. Solid-state CD spectra of MOF-1, MOF-4, and MOF-5 are consistent with the presence of SBU-based helical motifs. MOF-3-MOF-5 show excellent selective CO2 gas sorption. Toxic organic dye degradation properties with potential applications in environmental remediation and wastewater purification were found for all of the MOFs. Furthermore, trinuclear and hexanuclear Cu-pyrazolate unit (SBU-I and SBU-II) induced magnetic behavior of MOF-1 and MOF-3-MOF-5 highlights the usefulness of [Cu3(μ3-OH)(μ-Pyz)3] cluster based SBUs for magnetic MOF synthesis.

elements.content: All reagents used in the present work were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification unless otherwise stated. FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Nicolet MAGNA-IR 750 spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a Perkin–Elmer 2400 Series-II CHN Analyzer. Magnetic data were collected with SQUID-VSM and MPMS (Evercool, 7 T) instruments from Quantum Design. Thermal analyses were carried out with a TA Instruments SDT Q600 instrument under a nitrogenous atmosphere with a flow rate of 100 mL/min, and powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE instrument. Gas sorption studies were carried out using an ASAP 2020 instrument by Micromeritics, and UV–vis studies were performed using a CARY 100 Bio spectrometer by Varian.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All reagents used in the present work were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification unless otherwise stated. FT-IR spectra were obtained on a Nicolet MAGNA-IR 750 spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 Series-II CHN Analyzer. Magnetic data were collected with SQUID-VSM and MPMS (Evercool, 7 T) instruments from Quantum Design. Thermal analyses were carried out with a TA Instruments SDT Q600 instrument under a nitrogenous atmosphere with a flow rate of 100 mL/min, and powder X-ray diffraction patterns were collected on a Bruker D8 ADVANCE instrument. Gas sorption studies were carried out using an ASAP 2020 instrument by Micromeritics, and UV-vis studies were performed using a CARY 100 Bio spectrometer by Varian.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction intensities for all of the MOFs except MOF-5 were collected at 120 K on a Bruker APEX-2 CCD area diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation and processed using SAINT. The structures were solved by direct methods in SHELXS and refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2 in SHELXL. Data for MOF-5 were collected at 100 K on a Bruker D8VENTURE Microfocus diffractometer equipped with a PHOTON II Detector, with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), controlled by the APEX3 (v2017.3–0) software package and processed using SAINT. Raw data were integrated and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects using the Bruker APEX II/APEX III program suite. The structures were solved by direct methods in SHELXS and refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2 in SHELXL. Crystallographic data are summarized in , and CIF files for the structures reported in this paper have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC). Deposition numbers are given in . The structures were solved by direct methods in SHELXS and refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2 in SHELXL. Data for MOF-5 were collected at 100 K on a Bruker D8VENTURE Microfocus diffractometer equipped with a PHOTON II Detector, with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å), controlled by the APEX3 (v2017.3-0) software package and processed using SAINT. Raw data were integrated and corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects using the Bruker APEX II/APEX III program suite. The structures were solved by direct methods in SHELXS and refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2 in SHELXL. cln_elements.content:
Isophthalic acid (0.0166 g, 0.1 mmol) and 1H-pyrazole (0.204 g, 0.3 mmol) were taken up in a mixture of methanol, DMF, and water (3/1.5/1). To this mixture was slowly added an aqueous solution of Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.0241g, 0.1 mmol). The mixture was charged in a sealed bottle and stirred for a while before placing it inside an oven. It was heated at 80 °C for 72 h. After cooling block-shaped dark blue crystals were found. The crystals were then filtered, washed with methanol, and dried before proceeding with further studies (yield 52%).

Anal. Calcd (found) for C24H25Cu3N9O8: C, 38.02 (38.73); H, 3.32 (3.47); N, 16.63 (17.02). IR KBr (cm–1): 3500 (s), 3365 (s), 3317 (b), 2929 (s), 1664 (s), 1608 (s), 1562 (s), 1490 (s), 1382 (s), 1340 (s), 1280 (s), 1178 (s), 1058 (s).

Synthesis of <bold>MOF-2</bold>

To a solution containing methanol, DMF, and water (3 mL/1 mL/1 mL) were added Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.0241 g, 0.01 mmol), pyrazole (0.0204 g, 0.03 mmol), and 5-ethynylisophthalic acid (0.0166 g, 0.01 mmol). Then the mixture was stirred for 10 min, transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave, and heated to 70 °C for 1 day. After slow cooling of the reaction mixture needle-shaped green crystals of MOF-2 were obtained; they were washed with methanol and dried (yield 45%).

Anal. Calcd (found) for C32H43Cu3N11O12: C, 39.85 (40.24); H, 4.49 (4.57); N, 15.98 (16.18). IR KBr (cm–1): 3373 (b), 3286 (ms), 3130 (ms), 1654 (s), 1618 (s), 1569 (s), 1490 (s), 1380 (s), 1353 (s), 1278 (s), 1180 (s), 1058 (s).

Synthesis of <bold>MOF-3</bold>

MOF- 3 was synthesized similarly to MOF-1 except 5-azidoisophthalic acid was used instead of isophthalic acid. After slow cooling block-shaped dark blue crystals were obtained. The crystals were collected from the solution, washed with methanol, and dried (yield 58%).

Anal. Calcd (found) for C52H60Cu6N26O18: C, 36.34 (35.85); H, 3.52 (3.61); N, 21.19 (21.37). IR KBr (cm–1): 3598 (s), 3380 (b), 2927 (s), 2119 (s), 1658 (s), 1610 (s), 1488 (s), 1365 (s), 1278 (s), 1180 (s), 1101 (s), 1058 (s).

Synthesis of <bold>MOF-4</bold>

The synthesis of MOF- 4 was analogous to that of MOF-1 except 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid was used instead of isophthalic acid. Small block-shaped blue crystals were obtained after slow cooling. These were then filtered, washed, and dried (55% yield).

Anal. Calcd (found) for C49H53Cu6N19O22: C, 35.86 (36.07); H, 3.25 (3.32); N, 16.21 (16.28). IR KBr (cm–1): 3352 (s), 3234 (s), 3137 (s), 1654 (s), 1568 (s), 1488 (s), 1379 (s), 1276 (s), 1178 (s), 1103 (s), 1060 (s).

Synthesis of <bold>MOF-5</bold>

MOF-5 was synthesized similarly to MOF-1 except 5-aminoisophthalic acid was used instead of isophthalic acid. Green needle-shaped crystals were found after cooling. The crystals were then filtered, washed, and dried (yield 67%).

Anal. Calcd (found) for C34H29Cu6N14O23: C, 29.53 (29.62); H, 2.11 (2.14); N, 14.18 (14.36). IR KBr (cm–1): 3377 (b), 2995 (b), 1660 (s), 1571 (s), 1473 (s), 1409 (s), 1375 (s), 1276 (s), 1176 (s), 1058 (s).

Then the mixture was stirred for 10 min, transferred to a Teflon-lined autoclave, and heated to 70 °C for 1 day. After slow cooling of the reaction mixture needle-shaped green crystals of MOF-2 were obtained; they were washed with methanol and dried (yield 45%).

Anal. Calcd (found) for C32H43Cu3N11O12: C, 39.85 (40.24); H, 4.49 (4.57); N, 15.98 (16.18). IR KBr (cm-1): 3373 (b), 3286 (ms), 3130 (ms), 1654 (s), 1618 (s), 1569 (s), 1490 (s), 1380 (s), 1353 (s), 1278 (s), 1180 (s), 1058 (s).

Synthesis of MOF-3 

 MOF- 3 was synthesized similarly to MOF-1 except 5-azidoisophthalic acid was used instead of isophthalic acid. After slow cooling block-shaped dark blue crystals were obtained. The crystals were collected from the solution, washed with methanol, and dried (yield 58%).

Anal. Calcd (found) for C52H60Cu6N26O18: C, 36.34 (35.85); H, 3.52 (3.61); N, 21.19 (21.37). IR KBr (cm-1): 3598 (s), 3380 (b), 2927 (s), 2119 (s), 1658 (s), 1610 (s), 1488 (s), 1365 (s), 1278 (s), 1180 (s), 1101 (s), 1058 (s).

Synthesis of MOF-4 

The synthesis of MOF- 4 was analogous to that of MOF-1 except 5-hydroxyisophthalic acid was used instead of isophthalic acid. Small block-shaped blue crystals were obtained after slow cooling. These were then filtered, washed, and dried (55% yield).

Anal. Calcd (found) for C49H53Cu6N19O22: C, 35.86 (36.07); H, 3.25 (3.32); N, 16.21 (16.28). IR KBr (cm-1): 3352 (s), 3234 (s), 3137 (s), 1654 (s), 1568 (s), 1488 (s), 1379 (s), 1276 (s), 1178 (s), 1103 (s), 1060 (s).

Synthesis of MOF-5 

 MOF-5 was synthesized similarly to MOF-1 except 5-aminoisophthalic acid was used instead of isophthalic acid. Green needle-shaped crystals were found after cooling. The crystals were then filtered, washed, and dried (yield 67%).

Anal. Calcd (found) for C34H29Cu6N14O23: C, 29.53 (29.62); H, 2.11 (2.14); N, 14.18 (14.36). IR KBr (cm-1): 3377 (b), 2995 (b), 1660 (s), 1571 (s), 1473 (s), 1409 (s), 1375 (s), 1276 (s), 1176 (s), 1058 (s).

cln_elements.content:
The 2D grid networks subsequently undergo stacking along the crystallographic a axis, sustained by various intergrid hydrogen bonds, π–π stacking, and weak interactions. This results in an interesting situation with a considerable amount of cavities inside a noninterpenetrating network. However, as far as the void space inside the cavity is concerned, a contrasting picture can be observed for MOF-3 and MOF-4. The volume of the total solvent-accessible void space calculated by PLATON was found to be negligible for MOF-3, while that of MOF-4 is 471.7 Å3, which is approximately 13% of the unit cell volume. This is consistent with crystal structures with MOF-3 where pore channels are mostly filled with coordinated as well as lattice solvent molecules.

The above considerations prompted us to investigate the N2, CO2, and CH4 gas sorption behavior of MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5. To perform the study, the MOF samples were first soaked in a methanol and DCM (1/1) solution for 12 h in order to exchange the trapped solvent molecules. After the solvent exchange process was repeated three times, the samples were then dried under vacuum at 110 °C before being taken to the instrument. Nitrogen gas sorption was carried out at 77 K to determine the surface area under the pressure range of 0–1 atm. However, CO2 and methane gas adsorption studies were done at 273 K in the aforementioned pressure range. All three MOFs exhibit moderate to poor uptake of N2 gas. MOF-1 and MOF-3 absorbed 20 and 40 cm3/g, respectively (Figures S17 and S18 in the Supporting Information), whereas MOF-4 and MOF-5 absorbed ca. 7 and 10 cm3/g of N2, respectively. Interestingly, both MOF-4 and MOF-5 show reasonably high uptake of CO2, which are in stark contrast to the absorbance properties of MOF-1 and MOF-3 with poor uptake. Both MOFs show a typical type I isotherm, and as the pressure approaches 1 atm the adsorption of CO2 reaches a plateau at 23.1 and 38 cm3/g for MOF-4 and MOF-5, respectively (). In order to confirm the selective CO2 gas sorption over other gases, we also performed CH4 gas sorption studies for all three MOFs. The results show poor uptake of CH4 gas and henceforth confirmed the selective CO2 gas sorption ability of MOF-4 and MOF-5.

Magnetic Studies

dc magnetic susceptibilities were performed on polycrystalline samples of MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5 (). Room-temperature χM T (χM = molar magnetic susceptibility) values are 0.98, 1.0, 1.06, 1.61 cm3 mol–1 K for MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5, respectively. All of the χM T values at 300 K are lower than the theoretical calculated value of 1.125 cm3 mol–1 K for three uncoupled Cu­(II) centers (g = 2) for MOF-1, MOF-3, and MOF-4, whereas the theoretical value of six uncoupled Cu­(II) centers (g = 2) is 2.25 cm3 mol–1 K (g = 2) for MOF-5. Lower values are most probably due to the presence of antiferromagnetic interactions at room temperature. χM T plots are decreased with a decrease in the temperature due to antiferromagnetic exchange with neighboring Cu­(II) centers. Minimum values of 0.31, 0.15, 0.38, and 0.45 cm3 mol–1 K were obtained at 2 K for MOF-1 and MOF-3–MOF-5, respectively. We tried to fit the magnetic data using the model. However, due to the large number of magnetic exchange pathways with complicated structures, it was not possible to fit with any simplified model.
